Comment: Have you thanked Wyoming, Utah, or Nevada yet?   California imports the most energy in the US by almost a factor of 3. Want to guess where it comes from? Wyoming, Alabama, Illinois, Arizona, West VA are the largest producers and exporters. California imports multiple times what most states even use.   With no exaggeration: North Dakota, West VA, and Pennsylvania power the cities of the East Coast. And Wyoming and Arizona power much of the American southwest.   Water? Well, 25% of that water is from other states - imperial county specifically gets almost all its agriculture water from a river that California doesn't even border. That dam that provides the water was a public works project paid for wh n California was hardly even 5 million people, and the rest of the Southwest was practically an uninhabited desert. Which, let's be clear, it would be if it weren't for the bureau of reclamation damming everything that'll make a lake.   With a little change of perspective, California is the leech on the system, and tossing to middle finger to mother nature.   Implying that the states aren't inseparably connected at just about every level is simply asinine.  Edit: We need only look south of the border to see what the area would be like if it weren't for the major environment-manipulating megaprojects. The American southwest is a fishtank in a desert.

Comment: Sure the resources you pay for. The infrastructure and interstate transmission lines, Dam and Reservoir maintenance, River control, even something as simple as highways are built by the feds for Mutual benefit of all the states knowing that resources are not in every state.   My state has the single highest per-capita infrastructure cost in the nation. Why? Because urban centers are West of us, and the food is grown east of us. Neither could get to either if it weren't for infrastructure in my state. We have nowhere near the population to pay for that...so, what happens? The feds subsidize us so we can repair the infrastructure that benefits other states. It only makes sense that other states pay for it - it doesn't economically benefit us at all.   Hell, Wyoming has the most road per capita than any state, and they hardly have 500k people to pay for it.  But if it weren't for those roads, multiple states and urban centers would be going dark.   Remember, a lot of this stuff isn't state built. This stuff was built by the feds, maintenance was given to the states, and standards are in place. I would love nothing more than for my state to give up maintenance of an info structure grid that benefits other states - it's like 1/3 of our budget. But that will collapse multiple systems that others rely on.   You know how Texas is having  power grid issues constantly now? And severe price volatility? That's because they went to their own grid. They silo'd themselves. The feds have done the opposite to ensure that every state has every resource they need. And yes, it's paid for by everyone, but only the ones who have the infrastructure need to maintain it....and those are states with the natural resources...which tend to be low population conservative states.

Comment: Here’s the deal: That claim is a half-truth often thrown around for political effect, but the reality is more nuanced.  Is California the “highest” in welfare per capita?  It depends on how you define “welfare.” If you’re talking about traditional Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF), California has historically had a larger share of the nation’s caseload because it has higher benefits and broader eligibility compared to many other states. However, if you include programs like SNAP (food stamps), Medicaid, or housing assistance, the rankings shift — and some red states (like Louisiana, Mississippi, and West Virginia) often top those lists on a per capita basis, especially for SNAP and Medicaid.  Why does California have a high number of welfare recipients?  Simple: it’s the most populous state, and it has some of the highest housing costs and income inequality. Many working people still qualify for aid because wages haven’t kept up with the cost of living. California’s safety net is also intentionally designed to be more accessible than many conservative states, where eligibility rules can be much stricter.  And yes, California is very blue.  It leans heavily liberal on most social policies, and its state government supports a more expansive social safety net. But the idea that “liberal = more welfare” is oversimplified. Many of the poorest states (and highest aid recipients per capita) are actually deep red states with conservative leadership — they just receive a lot of federal aid.  TL;DR:  California does have a large welfare caseload, partly due to its size, high cost of living, and more inclusive policies. But “highest per capita” depends on the program, and several red states are right up there (or higher) on various forms of assistance.

Comment: That actually makes total sense, and I appreciate the breakdown. You’re right — infrastructure like that doesn’t recognize state lines, and the benefits flow far beyond the borders where the physical resources or roads sit. It’s a shared system, and without federal support, a lot of it wouldn’t be economically sustainable for the individual states tasked with maintaining it.  I also totally get the frustration of having to shoulder that cost locally when the real benefit is regional or even national. The Wyoming example is a perfect illustration. People forget that someone has to pay to keep those arteries open, and often it’s the folks who live where the infrastructure happens to be — not the ones profiting from the access.  The Texas grid example really drives it home: going solo on critical infrastructure can sound good on paper, until it doesn’t work.  Thanks for laying it out so clearly. I’m with you on this — it’s complicated, but the math checks out.

Comment: Japan's housing industry is facing the reality that it is possible to have "too much of a good thing." That's because while America's real estate industry is wrestling with a lack of availability that has caused a [housing crisis](https://www.benzinga.com/real-estate/24/05/38966556/why-home-prices-in-the-u-s-have-surged-by-nearly-50-since-2020?utm_campaign=partner_feed&utm_source=yahooFinance&utm_medium=partner_feed&utm_content=site), Japan has a housing crisis for the exact opposite reason. It's an oversupply of properties, not a lack of inventory, roiling Japan's housing market.  According to Japan's Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, nearly 9,000,000 vacant properties exist in Japan. The current tally represents an additional 500,000 vacancies that have hit the market since the last time the Ministry released these statistics in 2018. Japan's vacancy rate has surged by 80% in the last 20 years. Nearly 14% of Japan's homes are vacant, and the average in rural areas is closer to 20%.  May 2024

Comment: I’m going to push back on that, because honestly, that argument doesn’t hold up.  First, the idea that California’s problems are because people aren’t “proving citizenship” to get benefits is political spin, not fact. The vast majority of social services are accessed by U.S. citizens, not undocumented people. And tying the homeless crisis to immigration is just a distraction from the real issues.  Let’s be clear: the homelessness crisis exploded because of a long history of failed housing policy, mental health system collapse, and lack of affordable options—not because of “safe injection sites” or needle exchanges. People didn’t suddenly become homeless because someone gave them a clean needle. They became homeless because rent outpaced wages, mental health care was gutted, and shelters weren’t built because NIMBYs fight them at every turn.  You mention California wages—but those numbers don’t reflect reality for the vast majority of workers. Yes, tech and union trades pay well. But most people aren’t in tech or in a union. Try talking to teachers, grocery clerks, restaurant workers, gig drivers, or health aides scraping by at $20 an hour while gas is $6 and rent is $2,500 for a one-bedroom. That’s the California story for millions.  As for taxes—yes, California taxes heavily. No argument there. But blaming taxes alone is lazy economics. States like Texas and Florida might brag about no state income tax—but they hit working people harder with property taxes, sales taxes, toll roads, and regressive fees. Meanwhile, their wages are lower, healthcare is worse, and worker protections are weaker.  You want to make it political? Fine. Here’s the politics: this isn’t about red or blue. It’s about whether leadership at any level is willing to actually address root causes instead of scapegoating immigrants and people struggling with addiction.  It’s easy to throw blame at the most visible target. It’s harder to talk about systemic failure across the board.

Comment: You’re the one who said $2,500 for a one-bedroom—not me. I was responding directly to the number you gave.  But even if we use your revised $1,500 figure, it doesn’t change the reality for a huge portion of people here. You can cherry-pick teacher salaries and union jobs all day—but not everyone in California is a teacher, a programmer, or in a trade. There are millions of service workers, caregivers, janitors, restaurant staff, retail employees, and others who aren’t pulling six figures and still face the same high costs for food, gas, utilities, and basic survival.  Saying “just learn to code” or “get into a trade” ignores the structural barriers a lot of people face—including access to training, time, child care, and mental health support. It also assumes that every person’s value is tied to their ability to upskill into whatever job you personally respect.  And yes—you absolutely did bring up undocumented people and drug users in your argument about what’s wrong with California. You can’t throw that out there and then pretend you didn’t.  I’m not arguing that California doesn’t have serious problems. I’ve said repeatedly that it does. But scapegoating the most vulnerable people while dismissing the lived experience of millions as “playing victim” isn’t the flex you think it is. It’s just lazy.
